description.text:
I've recently been doing a large number of longer prints overnight and have had a few where the filament has run out and continued to print. Which is very annoying.

Now that I'm using OctoPrint to run my printer I'm able to install a plugin that will detect whether there is filament going into the extruder. I have my printer in an enclosure which is smaller left to right so I'm using a different reel holder so I wasn't able to use the existing filament sensors on here. I have a bunch of these lever switches laying around:

https://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B008SO0IGQ/

So I designed a mount that will attach to the holes in the top of the extruder body and feed the filament through keeping the switch closed. Once the filament runs out the switch opens and using the Filament Sensor Reloaded plugin my printer will pause and move the print head and wait for new filament to be inserted and the print to be resumed :D

The holes are supposed to be 2mm and I used some 1.5mm copper rod to hold the switch in place and help hold the two halves together as it was a very tight fit. As I printed it in ABS some acetone was also dripped along the seam and the whole thing clamped while the two halves bonded.

description.text:
I just got some Pagoda-2 antennas from Farvew.com and they provide an STL for a protective shell but I was concerned about the disks getting out of alignment, so I whipped up some spacers. The design thickness for the top is 3.65mm and the bottom is 10.45, but on my printer they come out a hair thicker than that so I used a bit of sandpaper and a caliper to get them to exactly the proper thickness.

I was planning to secure them with shrink tubing but the only size I had that fit was quite a bit bigger than necessary, and thus the first time I tried to fully shrink the lower section I melted the spacer a bit. What I ended up doing was using a bit of UV epoxy to seal the edges of the pcb to where it meets the spacers. Glue should also be fine. For EXTRA protection, one could even use this And the outer shell at the same time.

Korbanth "DV6" Darth Vader RotJ Lightsaber Chassis.

Sorry its nothing too flashy, I remixed the entire thing from a Graflex 2.0 chassis I found here, and did so to hold standard lightsaber electronics in the DV6 (as it was designed for an Arduino w/ string blade). Its definitely different from most chassis systems out there, and it got kind of ugly from weird things NetFabb did to it, but I think it will work fine.

THIS IS A TWO-PART CHASSIS!
You'll need to print the Main file and then the file thats associated with your soundboard. If you order this, 3D Hubs will automatically fill your cart with all the files. That means if you want to use a NBv3 in your DV6, you will need remove the NEC and the CF/PC versions from the cart. You should only see the Main and NBv3 parts left, and then order those.

Despite it's looks, it holds everything one could want in a saber. Your standard 18650 battery, most soundboards, speaker. On top that, a Switchcraft recharge port, Crystal Chamber with a hole to mount a 5mm accent LED.

Everything is fairly self-explanatory with it, but there are a few important things to note:
-Soundboards might need a bit of force to get in, but its a nice and tight grip to keep it in place. Be very careful of the wiring, and organize your wires to come out of the main opening or through the channel.
-30 gauge wire is needed for the switches and LED.
-I figure the order of install should be: Accent LED, recharge port, and then speaker. It doesn't matter the order for other parts.
-I found it easier to remove the chassis once the grip section was screwed off from the switch section. The chassis is really nice and tight, and couldn't pull it out through the pommel. In all honesty, you'll probably never remove the chassis once it installs. Even if you need to make a fix, you'll could pull it out just a bit to separate the soundboard piece, unless the battery failed or something (which is why you don't get bad off-brand batteries).
-With that in mind, planning to access the chassis by removing the grip section will result is less wiring that goes past the 18650. In turn, reduce the amount of wiring you have to cram in under the LED unit. Which is a real good thing.

Uploaded stream of DV6 build, using this chassis: https://youtu.be/UVfZkG1-ao4

Give a like to my FB page for weekly live-stream lightsaber builds, cosplay, props, and whatever else I want to post about: https://www.facebook.com/thescarletimpaler/

Update Log:

25 Feb 2017:
-Uploaded a new NEC version. It now has a wire channel underneath the board. This will be for other variants.
-Just started the test print for the Nano Biscotte V3 variant and the Crystal Focus and Petit Crouton variant. Sorry, I don't think I will able to adapt the Color Extender board for this chassis.

26 Feb 2017:
-Test fits for Nano Biscotte v3 and Petit Crouton/Crystal Focus were good to go. Their files are uploaded.

description.text: This is my version of Fan Blower Hood (Shroud). One that fits perfectly on Geeetech i3, and that it don't obstruct air flow. For fixing, you need two M3x10 mm screws, with allan screw head or any similar. And, blower fan does not require any bolts and nuts - it holds by tight fit. description.text:
I love the Iron Throne made by Revennant, thank you very much for this great work. But the base wasn't really my choise, so I cutted the old base off on my first print of this throne and printed without any base at all (http://www.thingiverse.com/make:303776).
Than I saw a make of the throne with another base (http://www.thingiverse.com/make:304512). Txispas shared his base and now for those who don't want to fiddle around with the stl and obj files here is the ready-to-print remix.

If you aren't printing on a raft and aren't afraid of loosing some details on the bottom, then set the z position offset in your slicer to -1.0mm, this would stick the bottom great to the printing bed.

description.text:
This is for the printing and shipping of a 3D printed set of Enhanced Spawning Pillars.

3D replacements for the Arcadia Quest's 2D enemy spawn tiles.

OVERVIEW:

These components boast the following upgraded features:

  • Vertical Display - Stands up so they're easier to spot on the board
  • Ornate Design - Constructed to mesh well with the AQ aesthetic, these Pillars have a vastly upgraded visually look and assists in creating a more immersive gaming experience, as well as fitting seamlessly with the other 3D component add-ons.

ALTERNATIVE GAMEPLAY OPTION:

There are 3 methods to place Spawn Pillars when setting up your Arcadia Quest game:

  1. Put the 3D Spawn Pillars in a bag, and randomly pull one from the bag, as needed when setting up the board.
  2. Keep the standard 2D tiles, place them (if the campaign book calls for the "?" tokens), then once revealed, replace the 2D tokens with 3D Spawn Pillars
  3. Keep the standard 2D tiles, place them (if the campaign book calls for a specific token in a specific tile/zone), then just place the 3D Spawn Pillars

Full Set - (x5) Spawn Pillars - This quantity will function with both the Core or Inferno sets

NOTE: Only one set is needed to play. You may purchase more if:

  • You want to paint each set differently to match the theme of specific versions, etc
  • You want to play an expanded version of the game with MORE of everything

GAME USAGE & AVAILABILITY:

NOTE: The following AQ products come with Spawn Tokens

  • Core box (8 double-sided tokens - blue & pink)
  • Inferno box (10 double-sided tokens - blue & pink)

ASSEMBLY PROCESS:

No assembly required.

CREDITS:

These are an original design, inspired by the artwork of Arcadia Quest, the board game by CMON.

PRINT SERVICES:

If you are interested in this print but do NOT have a 3D printer, please consider going to my Etsy store before paying to have it printed somewhere else. If you already own a 3D printer, enjoy this file. If you do sell prints of this item, I would greatly appreciate a tip for the design effort that was involved in creating it. Thank you. https://www.etsy.com/shop/BeardedBuddhaGaming

description.text: Based on the laser cut Bus Pirate case.  Seeing as I didn't have a laser cutter but did have a Makerbot I decided to print one instead.

If you are printing this from anything other than PLA or natural ABS you will want to consider how you will be able to see the status LEDs. The red LEDs can be seen easily through ABS, the greens can be seen but are quite dim. Also the inside of the case is a snug fit. Depending on the tolerance of your machine and how well the board was cut you may want to either edit the blender file or simply scrape away a little from the inside of the case. For me I had to scrape away just a fraction of a millimeter.

title: Anet A8 Y Belt Tensioner Improved

description.text:
Hi.

I recently bought my anet, and started printing some upgrades.
One of those was a belt tensioner. I printed 4 of them (all available here). However all of them broke a few prints later, and the last one didn't even fit the Anet A8 (even been designed for it). So I created my own from scratch, based on the A8 original one.
On of the problems of other designs is the pressure angle (I did the same mistake on my first test). As the belt is above the 4 square holes, the tension made is something near to 15 degrees, and this caused them to broke on the knee.
I applied a base that makes this tension almost 0. However this belt tensioner need you to also have the frame brace on this thing (http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1430727).

Finally I also applied 2 end caps from this model (http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1908554). The 2 screws distribute the pressure move evenly.

note: this one already did more than 36h of printing without any issues.

Printer:

Anet A8

Rafts:

Yes

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.2

Infill:

100

Notes:

The model correspondes to the LEFT brace (looking to the Anet). To print the Right one just mirror it in the X axis.
Maybe some sanding needed after print (depends on the quality of the printing)

title: Temp calibration
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text: Custom (and yet another) temperature control/calibration test.

Printer Brand:

Prusa

Printer:

Prusa Steel

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

No

Resolution:

.25

Notes:

It was thinked to be printed at 0.2 resolution (every 50 layers you change the temperature)
But it can also be printed at 0.25 (like in this case) but every 40 layers you change the temp.
it could also be printed at 0.1 or less but i dont think it's really needed...

No need for top or bottom, and 1 wall is enough.

Why this one? why make another one?

I didn't like to print a square, because it was too many unnesessary walls...
a circle could have been a good idea, but i wouldn't be able to see how temp affected sharp edges. so I decided to do this "oval" shape.
It has some "lines" so you get a very specific mark and you dont need to mark them afterwards.
It's shape, allows it to be print at really fast speeds too.
(ignore the random dots in mine, that was because i was testing random retraction points too)

Set printer at 0.20 or 0.25 layer height. At temperature control:
(if set at 0.25)
Change the temperature every 40 layers. So: 1-41-81-121-161
(if set at 0.20)
Change the temperature every 50 layers. So: 1-51-101-151-201-

This is a machine for creating printed circuit boards. It works by shooting an UV laser to a photosensitive film applied to the copper clad board.
Parts needed (links just for reference):
2x nema 17 steppers
4x 8mm diameter rods
8x 8mm bushing (https://www.aliexpress.com/item/10pcs-SF-1-0810-Self-Lubricating-Composite-Bearing-Bushing-Sleeve-8-10-10mm/1393921440.html)
1x PC case(or wooden box)
2x M5 threaded rods
8x M5 nuts
2x stepper motor coupler (http://www.ebay.com/itm/5x5mm-CNC-Motor-Jaw-Shaft-Coupler-5mm-To-5mm-Flexible-Coupling-OD-19x25mm-LU-/162331234217?var=&hash=item25cbb20fa9:m:m3W6cN0V5fJUprqoNVIGbfw)
20x M3 screws and nuts
1x 50mW+ UV laser (http://www.ebay.com/itm/New-Metal-Laser-Diode-LD-SLD3232VF-Fit-For-SONY-405nm-50mw-CW-Violet-Blue-1PC-/232136388708?hash=item360c683064:g:sj8AAOSwB09YIEZg)
1x laser housing (http://www.ebay.com/itm/2pcs-12x40mm-Metal-Housing-Case-for-5-6mm-TO-18-Laser-Diode-w-200nm-1100nm-Lens-/252086841192?hash=item3ab18bef68:g:mbwAAOSw4SlV8R~r)
1x laser heatsink (http://www.ebay.com/itm/Promotion-Special-Offer-Cooling-Heatsink-Heat-Sink-for-12mm-Laser-Diode-Module-/231319696413?hash=item35dbba741d:g:LggAAOSwEK9UAJH8)
4x MR95ZZ bearings
2x springs, ID: 6mm, length: 10mm
2x a4988 (or DRV8825) stepper drivers
2x a4988 extension board (http://www.ebay.com/itm/A4988-DRV8825-3D-Printer-Stepper-Motor-Driver-Control-Extension-Boards-/321746391773?hash=item4ae99452dd:g:KI8AAOSwBLlVSJB3) [optional]
1x STM32F103C8T6 development board (http://www.ebay.com/itm/ARM-Cortex-M3-STM32F103C8T6-STM32-Minimum-System-Development-Board-/381374722304?hash=item58cbb47100:g:S0cAAOxyni9S~0Fd)
1x laser driver or current limiter
1x transistor or mosfet for laser PWM

Firmware: https://github.com/bngreen/Engraver-Firmware
Host Application: https://github.com/bngreen/Engraver-Host
Electronics: https://circuitmaker.com/Projects/Details/Bruno-Green/Engraver [untested]

Instructions coming soon

Safety Concerns

Always wear appropriate (wavelength and OD rating) safety glasses rated for the wavelength of your laser, even 5mW lasers can be dangerous to your eyes.
Driving the laser with PWM and low duty rate does NOT makes it safe to be looked at with naked eyes
Be careful with reflective surfaces, most of the goggles does not protects you from laser reflections. Do not point the laser to your eyes (or of others) even with the safety glasses.

remixed_from.title: Filament Guide for monoprice maker select or Wanhao i3

title: Filament Guide for Monoprice Maker Select/Wanhao Duplicator i3/Cocoon Create

description.text:
I initially downloaded John21's filament guide but found it to be too thick for the existing screws on my printer to reach through to the frame, so I have reduced the thickness of the guide to 2mm, half of the original 4mm, to allow the existing screws on the filament spool holder to be used. I also modified the hole to be less prone to letting go of filament during X axis movement.

If your printer struggles to produce a nice-looking top layer, you should flip this model over in your slicer so that the bed side faces up and the ugly side faces down.

Printer:

Monoprice Maker Select V2

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Infill:

15%

Installation
  1. Unscrew and remove the filament spool holder on top of your printer.
  2. Run the screws through the holes on the spool holder and then place the guide below that.
  3. Place the new assembly atop your printer and screw back in as you would normally with the spool holder.

Modification to Original
  1. Squished the item in Tinkercad to be half as thick.
  2. Closed up the existing filament entry opening and created a new one with a channel to go through using hole boxes in Tinkercad.

It has been a while since I uploaded something to this website but I figured I should start sharing my creations in hopes they might benefit others down the road.

This is a built-from-scratch 40mm fan with pivot arm that runs on a small hobby motor. The DC motor is a 6V one that I salvaged from an old inject printer, so sadly I have no further information on it. The fan shroud has two clip on points so a second fan shroud could be attached to redirect the air flow. 3 small screws attach the fan shroud to the motor mount. The pivot arm uses a M4 bolt and nut and is approximately 65 mm long. The fan blades pressure fit to the motor coupling. If it's a little lose you can wrap the coupling in Teflon tape to make it a tighter fit.

Made in Fusion360: http://a360.co/2lEuxWa

This was originally designed to cool the DC motor to a water pump I built, that is what the background of the pictures are. Works well and is a little more nosier than a 40mm pc fan.

This is for the printing and shipping of a 3D printed set of Enhanced Portals & Vortexes. (Unpainted)

3D replacements for the Arcadia Quest's 2D portal tiles.

OVERVIEW:

These components boast the following upgraded features:

  • Vertical Display - Stands up so they're easier to spot on the board
  • Interchangeable Vortexes - Offering a variety of uses and the ability to upgrade with new vortex 3D patterns and materials in the future. This uses a Snap-In method to apply the Vortexes into the Portal bases
  • Ornate Portals - Constructed to mesh well with the AQ aesthetic, this Stone Portal base gives a vastly upgraded visually look and assists in creating a more immersive gaming experience

SETS TYPES:

  • Full Set - (x10) Portals with (x10) Spiral Vortexes - This quantity will function with both the Core or Inferno sets individually
  • 1 Pair - (x2) Portals with (x2) Spiral Vortexes

GAME USAGE & AVAILABILITY:

NOTE: The following AQ products come with portals:

  • Core box (8 double-sided tokens - blue & pink)
  • Inferno box (10 double-sided tokens - blue & pink)

ASSEMBLY PROCESS:

The optimal method of snapping together is to snap the vortex (plug) in and out of the back (non-rune side)

CREDITS:

These are an original design, inspired by the artwork of Arcadia Quest, the board game by CMON.

PRINT SERVICES:

If you are interested in this print but do NOT have a 3D printer, please consider going to my Etsy store before paying to have it printed somewhere else. If you already own a 3D printer, enjoy this file. If you do sell prints of this item, I would greatly appreciate a tip for the design effort that was involved in creating it. Thank you. https://www.etsy.com/shop/BeardedBuddhaGaming

description.text:
The arch is probably the most classic design for the mac stand.

For a mac stand, I only have 3 requirements: usable, simple and looks nice(very personal). This design fits them all.

This stand is for MBP 13' retina. the dimension of the upper most part of the opening on the top is 18mm. A scaling may make the stand fit for other models of mbp, I didn't try it.

The mac_stand_v2 is with an opening whose upper opening dimension is 18mm and the lower opening dimension is 15mm, this design provides a firm grip of your mbp.

The mac_stand_v3_not_so_tight version is with an opening whose upper opening and lower opening dimensions are always 18mm, and the mbp can be put into and pull out easily.

title: Prusa I3 Geeetech Pro B fan duct for hotend

description.text:
I previously used the parasitic fan duct designed for Geeetech's Prusa I3 Pro B but found it leaked a lot of air. Other designs on thingiverse required another fan, screws, etc. I set out to create a fan unit that could use the existing fan and screws, require no glue or additional parts, and could redirect more air to the hot end.

This fan duct unit is telescopic so that the duct can adjust vertical height based on the user's needs. It redirects 50% of airflow to the hot end. The cold end remains sufficiently cool.

Insert the heat sink, then the screws through the metal carriage to the extruder motor, then the fan (40x40x10).

Printer:

Geeetech Pro B Prusa I3

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.1

Infill:

10%

Notes:

I took the liberty of adding supports needed that break away easily.

STLs layouts are for optimal printing - no need to rotate.

Depending or your printer's calibration, you may need to file down some faces and corners so that pieces insert properly. Do not over file or there may be insufficient friction to hold pieces in place.

This is a fairly detailed general eukaryotic cell (animal). It has all of the general organelles from Golgi bodies to ribosomes in accurate shapes and scaled to the size of the cell. This model can be printed to show middle schoolers an example of a cell in early science learning or it can be given during lectures to high schoolers so they can see and feel what is on the screen.

middle school: pass around pre printed cell and let children play with it to understand the workings of a cell.
high school: print out one object per person or per lab group and hand out during a lecture on cells, if you want punt numbers on the organelles that correspond to the lectures slides.

30-60minutes including lecture

author: thewerefox

description.text: This is another random model I decided to make using Illustrator and 123D Design. Kaskobi is well known throughout the launchpad community and is growing bigger each day. This is just a little thing I came up with just because I was bored. Anyways, look at the instructions on how I designed this and please go and check out some of my other models that I have posted on my profile.

Never Modeled an Actual Logo Before...

So how I started was I grabbed Kaskobi's logo off of Google images and threw it into a new sketch on Adobe Illustrator. Then, I used the pen tool to trace around his logo, this was easy since it was all straight lines. Next, I saved the outline as an SVG so I could load it into 123D Design. After I imported the SVG, I extruded his main logo up by .5" and then the rest I put at around .4" to make the logo stand out a lot more. Thanks for reading and if you like this, go check out some other 3D models I have made.

Hook_Number_1 = Acura

The protection I used (polystyrene) from the original packaging, started to dismantle! I bought a NinjaFlex filament only for this purpose: create a better replacement!
Note: my tripod is a Manfrotto 055CXPRO4 (replaced by the MT055CXPRO4), you may have to update the parameters to fit yours:

//--- Stopper size
h = 40;
r = 29.8;
flat = 14;
//--- podRadius
podRadius = 29.5;

Voilà,
Enjoy :)

PS. I use this standard library: MCAD/3d_triangle.scad.

Printer:

ZoneStar 802PNR2

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.2mm

Infill:

18%

Notes:

I use the NinjaFlex filament and struggled to get it printed! Here are my issues:

  • Extruder clogged: push up the Temperature (235°C)
  • No pressure enough on Extruder's pulley: put the 2 extruders in serial... (have a look at my printer picture). I have updated the firmware: mirroring feature, just magic!!
  • Anyway, every 3-4 layers, the filament started to run out the 2nd extruder's pulley. Only one thing to do... monitor it, pause the printing and replace the filament correctly. Not fun at all and a poor quality result.

Guess: I think I'll try a wider nozzle!
🌟Done🌟: AND IT'S WAY BETTER!! Check the updated picture 😃.

Settings:

  • Extruder temperature: 235°C
  • Bed: 50°C
  • nozzle: 0.8mm 🌟🆕🌟 (was 0.4mm)
  • Default extrusion width: 0.88mm 🌟🆕🌟
  • First layer: 180% (was 200%)
  • Layer height: 0.2mm
  • Solid layers: 5 top and 5 bottom (was 3)
  • Perimeters: 2 (was 3)
  • Speed: all at 15mm/s but the infill speed: 20mm/s
  • retractation: 0

-Despite this despicable quality, I can say... it's fully functional 😉.-
🌟🌟Look how nice it looks!🌟🌟

title: 3u Rack Shoes for Blackmagic Smartscope Duo

description.text:
These are 3u Rack "shoes" I created for desktop mounting of a device normally mounted in a 19" rack. It is designed to be used with a Blackmagic Smartscope Duo, but can be used for any 3u rack device that is very shallow in depth. A simple nut and bolt through the top two mounting holes is sufficient to hold the display as the bottom slot holds the bottom securely.

This design will work well for this device, as there are no controls on the device (buttons or switches) that need to be manipulated. It just needs to be held in a good viewing position.

I printed this in Pet-G,

I've included stl's for the right and left shoes and a dummy for the display.

title: Anycubic Kossel Mini Adjustable Heatbed Mount

description.text:
After Searching for some mounts that would work with my Anycubic Kossel Mini I found a decent mount created by Guco back in 2015 and adjusted it slightly allowing for more mount options, as well as greater range of adjustment.

http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:794505

I wanted something simple but that would let me adjust at all 6 mount points of my MK3 220mm heated bed. Finding something that would give me good access to the mounting screws as well as the adjustment screws was a challenge just because of where the holes in the heat bed lined up. Borrowing Guco's original design I modified it slightly to work with the extra screws and nuts you would be left with.

  • Made the mounting hole slightly larger to fit an M4 screws
  • raised the inset for the adjustment nut to work with M3 x 15 or larger

This set up works great with my Anycubic Kossel allowing me to level the bed at all 6 points with good accuracy.

remixed_from.author: infinati
remixed_from.title: Luke Skywalker Lightsaber : 8 Component, Super easy to print, Minimal support needed

title: Luke Skywalker Lightsaber: Remix to print in 3 pieces no support for fast churnout

description.text:
This is a remix of the Luke Skywalker Lightsaber : 8 Component, Super easy to print, Minimal support needed because when I printed that one without modification none of my 8 parts would fit together. The peg and hole sizes didn't match up for assembly.

Rather than fix it in the right way, I decided I wanted to print basically that same design in as few pieces as possible so I could churn out a few as fast as possible. So pretty much all I did was add a gradual "ramp up" to each of the areas that had overhang on the larger piece. This meant the buttons on the shaft are modified. The green arrows point to the button changes in one of my images. Also, the complicated upper piece I just split in half and laid flat so it could be printed more easily.

This absolutely modifies the aesthetics and probably not for the better, but I'm not going for super realism I'm going for spitting out a few of these things for kids to play with.

It will simply be super glued together after printing.

EDIT: Had some time to tweak a bit more as the printer was busy. Added a button and hole setup to the 3 bits as they stack vertically. I made sure the holes are larger than the corresponding buttons by a small bit, so glue will still be required to secure but alignment should be easier.

title: Flat Mount Full Graphic Smart Controller Case
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
A case that can be printed in 3 parts (plus a stop button) allowing convenient mounting of the controller on a flat surface. There are many cases for this controller, but none that did exactly what I wanted. I got inspiration from https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1562144 but it is designed to be picked up rather than attached to a surface.

I also used (and have included) the STL from http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:302196 as the basis for designing the case.

UPDATE: After printing and assembling this thing, I think there are some improvements that could be made:

  1. The Smart Controller that I have has the screen PCB mounted a couple of mm closer to the main board which, so I would make the screen surround to be slightly more flush.

  2. There was also not quite enough clearance under the rotary button, but I just pulled the button cap up slightly to fix that. If the top was more flush with the PCB, that may solve this issue too.

  3. The pillar that holds the screws wasn't strong enough and broke when I overtightened the screw the connects the end caps together. I fixed that by friction welding the end cap back on. I think if I wanted to print another one I would update the design so that the end caps just clicked on rather than screwed together.

  4. The original model of the controller board didn't have the through hole components protruding on the back of the board, so I neglected to make allowance for them. This is potentially a problem with the rotary button that has quite large through hole tabs. I just snipped the tab that was a problem a bit closer to the board and it actually is good for it to press against the bottom of the mount to give it a firm feel when you click it.

author: rustbubble

description.text:
From the "Don't try this at home kids" department....

My daughter has an orthodontic expander but lost the key yesterday. The orthodontist is closed for the week and she is supposed to have it cranked every day. I happened to have some nice stainless steel hex keys and for my first prototype bent one at an angle (see photo) and it was successful. Then using FreeCAD I designed a more elaborate thing as shown here.

The blue and white tool in the photo is what I am replacing with a 3D printed version. After it's printed I will cut down one of the hex keys and press fit it into the hub.

Edit: As soon as the glue dries, I can snap the yellow pieces together, and it will get used for at least a few days until the next orthodontist appointment.

Edit 27FEB2017:
I had a successful use of the home printed version on Saturday, then on Sunday my daughter found her original key so we went back to the OEM version. It was interesting to compare mine as printed with the OEM version- one feature lacking in mine was a little jog in the business end that keeps it from going in too deep and potentially scraping the roof of her mouth. Dimensionally otherwise my version was pretty close to the OEM version. Verdict: successful experiment.

No holiday feast at Hogwarts would be complete without magical floating candles. Why should you settle for anything less. The holders are easy and quick to print and allow you to Wingardium Leviosa as many led candles as you need to light your festive feasting hall. The first version is the strongest but requires the candles to be threaded on the fishing line (oh darn, now I've given away the trick) Version 2 and 3 can be hooked anywhere along the line which makes them a lot easier to install but they aren't as strong. Version 2 is best printed with a high strength filament like PETG, while version 3 is beefy enough it should work when printed in PLA.

The candles can be purchased in the darker recesses of Knockturn Alley, or, more simply, from Amazon. I used https://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B00P68DUGW but others of the same size should work as well.

The candles use an IR remote to turn on and off. Around the winter holidays we hang 4 dozen of these above the dining room table. You can hold down the button on the remote and make a grand sweeping gesture to turn them all on or off. Pretty close to magic the first time you do it.

We talked about this and a whole lot more on the 3D Printing Today podcast available on iTunes, or Stitcher radio learn more at http://www.threedprintingtoday.com/

This simple little chewing gum pot holder needs a little explanation.
I read somewhere that all the little bits of chewing gum that get spit out of a car window form a serious health hazard for sparrows and other small birds. To them it looks like bread, fills up their stomach but it does not digest. So despite the fact that they are full, they starve to death.

So I decided to no long spit my chewing gum out of the car, but where to put it? See here: the 2 pot solution. Fresh chewing gum in the first pot, used up chewing gum in the second put. Once the first pot is empty, put its lid on the second pot, put the first (now empty) pot in place of the second pot and open a fresh new full pot. (Still with me?) Then you can throw the full used up pot away. Simple, no?
I clip the holder in the side pocket of my door. Easy access.

There is a bridge in this design, as I wanted to make sure the pots do not slip through the bottom. But even if the bridge does not come out perfect, it doesn't matter much as it is hidden from view and is only there to hold the pots. You can smooth it out with a heat gun if you want.

remixed_from.title: Customizable stereographic picture projector v3 highres

description.text:
Big thanks to Joe Balint for coming up with the idea to use a skull for the stereographic projection!
I modified my script to create a difference from a hollowed out skull and the projected picture, so adding a light in the correct position should display the picture. This is just a proof of concept though, it may be hard to print or find the right spot to place the light. Later it might be possible to modify this into a full-blown lamp.
I have not printed it yet, but it slices just fine in Simplify3D. It will need support though.
The stl was converted with http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1383325

Edit: It looks like the Einstein projector does not slice in Simplify3D after all, seems I missed a problematic part when trying it out. Maybe other slicers can handle it. I will try to make a lower res version that works. The maze does work, so if you keep the border black or use thicker black/white areas around the border and set white_threshold below 1, like I did for the maze, it might work.

Edit2: I improved the base skull form and played around with the projection parameters a bit, this should give much better results. It still does not slice in Simplify3D, but now it is just minimal detail that is missing, probably I can find some working parameters when I have some time. The skull walls are now much thinner, there is more surface area touching the build platform and I cleared out the light path. I marked the northpole on three pictures, the projection angle is 45°. The maze will not work with walls as thin as that, so I'm leaving the old version here as it is working that way.

A lower resolution version, that actually slices in Simplify3D, is here: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2142104

title: just another fan holder for pla davinci pro 1.0

description.text:
just another fan holder for the davinci pro 1.0.

You do not need additional screws to fix the holder. It fits on the existing screws of the printhead.

I use a Titan TFD-B6015M12B fan.
https://www.nbm24.de/baumarkt/de/shop/Elektronik/Elektronik-Kategorie/Kuehlung-Lueftung/Gehaeuse-Luefter/?card=120238

You have to cut one screwhole of the fan. I used a Dremel. It is only fixed with two screws. The holes for the screws in the holder are 3mm. You can adjust the scad-file for other srews.

If you want to control the airflow I used this cheap fan control:
https://www.nbm24.de/baumarkt/de/shop/Elektronik/Elektronik-Kategorie/Kuehlung-Lueftung/Regelung-Steuerung/Stufenlose+Luefterregelung2C+Dre/?card=120477

To get power for the fan I did not want to change anything in the printer. I used an power extension cable to get 12V. It works really great and there is no danger for damage of solding directly to the printer. You find this cheap part here:
https://www.nbm24.de/baumarkt/de/shop/Elektronik/Elektronik-Kategorie/Kabel/Stromkabel-intern/?card=119749

There is an 60 cm extension for the fan-cable to. I used it to get a plug and cable.
So it is easy to change the fan:
https://www.nbm24.de/baumarkt/de/shop/Elektronik/Elektronik-Kategorie/Kabel/Stromkabel-intern/?card=120289

author: rgratp

title: Clamping bracket for sideway mounting of stepper motors

description.text:
This project addresses the need to mount Nema14/Nema17 stepper motors on a side wall, without using the motor's four screws holes on top (or bottom). This is useful when the top of the motor is equipped with some other mechanism (such as e.g. a direct extruder). The motor assembly can be inserted and removed quickly from the mounting bracket without the need to remove the top assembly.

The position of the mounting screws is configurable, so the screws can either be hidden inside the bracket (saving space) or be accessible outside from the outside. For outside screws, normal or countersunk versions are available.

The rear wall of the bracket has a configurable cutout for the motor wires. The bracket has holes and air channels to allow better air cooling when the motor get warm.

The motor is hold securely in place by means of two M3 clamp screws at the front edges of the bracket. Two M3 screw nuts hidden in the front corners provide the corresponding mating threads. When using grub screws, the clamping mechanism remains almost invisible from the outside.

The motor brackets are printed upside down, so no supports are needed for printing.

The OpenScad source is fully parametrized and commented, so that it can easily be adapted to special needs. Predefined ready-to-print versions are provided for Nema14 and Nema17 motors, with the mounting screw variants: inside countersunk, outside countersunk and outside normal screws.

Update 2017-03-04: I have added three STL files for Nema17 which give 3mm extra width (ew) at the rear for the motor wiring. This might be needed for motors which have a wire plug that is perpendicular to the motor axis.

comments.text: This is the design I'd like to use. Kindly tell me what the two different sized Nema17 mounts mean. There is a 34mm and 54mm. What do these measurements represent? Standing them both on their "feet" in Cura, I can see that the 34mm version is taller, with the "top" portion being thinner.

comments.text: The 34mm and 54mm are the distance between the mounting screw holes.  The 34mm version has the screws "inside", so it can be mounted right at the edge of the frame.  The 54mm version has the mounting screws on  the outside and thus needs some extra space on both sides.

description.text: Made this for a collegue's motorcycle!, Enjoy!

print_settings.Notes:: Unless you have a very good tuned printed, then you may not even need support.

description.text:
This is a universal mounting base plate for underneath your Bebop 2 drone. It clicks into place so you don't need to modify the drone frame. There are two 3 mm holes at the front and two holes at the back. At the back there are two M3 nuts inserted. This way you can attach anything you like to carry with you. I plan to make various kind of gadgets and will incorporate the links here as they come into existence.

The screw holes are positioned 34.5 mm from each other left to right, and 35.5 mm front to rear. The nuts lock into the design so you only need to tighten the screws. If you leave the base plate on without anything attached, it is wise to insert some dummy screws in order not to lose the nuts. The whole assembly weighs about 10 grams.

Important note: Whatever you attach, make sure the sensor has an unobstructed view.

Check out my designs of stuff to attach:
GoPro mount: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2139301

09-09-2017 Update: I removed the two smallest holes on the sides. That way it comes out a little cleaner and it doesn't add that much weight anyway. Check out Base Plate V2.

Printer:

Custom Prusa i3

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

0.5 mm nozzle, 0.2 mm layer height

Infill:

100%

Notes:

Since the base plate is only 2 mm thick you have to align the support structure density and the positioning of the printbed in order to get the supports exactly right in the large central hole. I have added two screenshots of the slicer preview to illustrate the desired support and its location.

Unless you have a very good tuned printed, then you may not even need support.

description.text: A small hook for curtains and other decorations

This is a replacement damper for the rubber part that is originally installed in the Parrot Bebop2. These rubber dampers are very soft and might cause oscillations around the roll axis with alternate control software as the Paparazzi autopilot. I had good results printing them in PETG, but PLA might also work. The original dampers will give a better picture when operating the camera and absorb more energy in case of a mishap.

The wider opening of the damper goes into the metal body of the Bebop2, the narrow goes to the plastic cross and is secured with the washer.

There is a damper-tool that can be used to fasten the special metal screw nut.

title: Anet A8 Power Supply Cover with 80mm Fan Remixed

description.text:
I remixed this Anet A8 power supply cover with 80mm fan from Ghrem who also remixed it from TNS and Bittig so thanks to those guys for the hard work.

I needed my switch to be located on the left as I have a different PSU and the 240v connections are on the left. Also I didn't want an additional LED switch or anything so I got rid of that.

This model fits and works very well.

I am using a 10A fused switch which is easily sourced on ebay or amazon.

Printer:

Anet A8

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

.02

Infill:

20

Notes:

2 walls and 2 top/bottom layers.

The screw on the left that is already in the PSU needs to be replaced with a M3 x 10mm (mine did anyway as the original M3 x 5mm didn't reach anymore).

The right hand side screw is a M3 x 15mm with a M3 nut inserted in the cover.

The screws holding the fan on are M3 x 20mm which fits perfect so that the screw doesn't hang out through the nut and contact the PSU frame.

This is replacement part for soap pump moving head. This design fits to http://methodproducts.co.uk hand soap pump. Just use some force, pull pump out and use some force and push this pump head in.

Head have separate cap so it would be possible to pull support structure out. Whole thing is clued together with acetone (in case of ABS).

Acetone threatment is a very good idea. it fills possible leak points.

Drilling nose holes larger after support structure removal and acetone threatment is also good idea

you can order one for 25 euro/dollar from me i am the designer.
The Beads and flower files cost 1 euro/dollar.

description.text:
This is an earbud holder designed to hide the cord away to protect it while it is being carried in a pocket or bag. To use this, put the earbuds in the holes with the cable coming out the hole in the outside ring, then turn the inner piece to wind the cord inside the body of the holder.

This design is very effective. It is not completely finished. There are a few parts I would like to improve but it works well enough that I haven't felt the need to finish it. I thought I should post it anyway.

This model took quite a few hours and lots of test printing to get right. If you appreciate my work, consider tipping me or head over to 3dupndown and download it there (each download is worth 5 cents to me WooHoo!).

I have added another STL with a larger gap between the inner and outer pieces. If you have had trouble with the pieces sticking together it may help. I have not tested it myself, if you do print it please let me know how it works.

Printer Brand:

MakerBot

Printer:

MakerBot Replicator 2

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.2mm works well

Notes:

This is a very precise print, the gap between the inner and outer part is about 0.4mm. If your printer has trouble with circles, blobbing or strings you may find it difficult to get a working print. Any warping of the base will also stop the inner part rotating freely.

After you have removed the raft you may need to twist the model to break the inner piece free. Depending on the quality of the print you may even need to pry them apart with a craft knofe.

The motion may not be smooth at first but with use they will wear away any roughness between the pieces and the motion will become smoother.

title: Geeetech i3 pro B e3d bowden mount with nut hole fixed

description.text:
With this remix I intended to "semi close" both nut holes, the bottom way. in this case.

didn't get the reason why initially was both way open, up and down. it's moderately tricky to insert and hold in position the nut, and inserting the bolt with the clamp and get the right height for the bolt to enter the nut...

this way you can slide the nut, and it won't fall. just slide the bolt, and it will catch the nut, without holding it in the right place.

easier mounting, that's it.

title: QIDI X-One ABS & PLA FFF files

description.text: The files attached are QIDI X-One PLA & ABS fff files. Beware these files are not perfect and should be verified with a test cube print. When printing a test cube watch the entire print layer by layer and note any issues you have. When making adjustments to your profiles only make one adjustment and print another cube. The process of printing test cubes may take several times to get right. If you make several adjustment you won't be able to know if your adjustment helped or not.

comments.text: I am sorry for such a stupid question but how do I use this fff file?
comments.author: HNieves

comments.text: In S3D go to file find import fff file. Import it. When it opens you can save profile as new. Save as new profile and rename it whatever you want.  When saving as new yo do it at top of S3D screen where your profile lists are.

title: Button : Proudly made by a Maker -30 and 26 mm

description.text:
Some days ago I lost two buttons of my jacket in just two days...

When I recovered the buttons, thinking that I'll have to sew them again, I realized how beatiful and full of face curves the design of a button is. I'm fascinated about these objects. They are a simple and small piece of art that do his job so well.

So I discovered myself thinking about made my own button and, at the end, I did it. I was so glad about the job that I decided to put the text: "Proudly made by a Maker".

Why I did my own button?

Because I'm a Maker.

Because I can.

You have the 30 mm (diameter) version and a 26 mm version with and without text. You also have the original freecad file to make your own buttons.

Wear them with proud!

PD: You can also access to the magnet version made by Akirasan. Thanks for the re design^^!

https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2203855

Printer:

Prusa i3 bq Hephestos

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

0,1

Infill:

20

Notes:

You have to print the buttons in VERTICAL. This is very important due to the face curves of the button and the small text. If you print a button in horizontal the result will be probably a mess. Remember also to put supports. I highly recommend to use a 0,1 mm resolution.

comments.text: As wacky as it sounds, this makes for a great remote camera setup. We utilized a stationary mavic to capture some events from over 1.8 miles away perched up high on a ledge. It gives the mavic a spy persona, especially with the ability to zoom in on subjects. With the propellers not in motion, the battery life is significantly increased and one could get up to an hour and a half of remote viewing with capability of a vertical axis scrolling. In extreme cases to prevent equipment capture, one could fly away with the tripod attached as long as it wasn't over 1/4th (2.3) lbs of the mavic's lifting capacity.

title: Fully printable PCB vise
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
Pretty self explanatory, it's a vise to hold PCBs steady when you are soldering your components.
The ball joint design gives you a fair bit of movement to position your work where it is most comfortable.
The main drive screw has reverse threads on one side to make the jaws clamp your PCB right in the middle of the vise.
The base has a few square holes for magnets to keep it steady on your workbench.
The vise can hold PCBs with a maximum width of 10cm.

The STLs are oriented the way I printed them on my Ultimaker and they were printed without a raft or support for minimum cleanup. The grooves of the jaws do need a bit of cleaning unless you've got retraction working well (I haven't bothered with that yet) but other than that the pieces should come out pretty much clean.
Please note that the threads are quite tight (at least on my print) and will require a bit of convincing the first few times. Add a bit of water to them to keep the heat down and work the pieces back and forth untill they work smoothly. I made them tight to minimise the flex in the jaws as you tighten them on your PCB.
The "swivel" and "bracket" parts have guide holes for short pieces of 3mm filament to aid alignment when gluing them together. I undersized the holes so you'll have to drill them out a bit if you decide to use them.
The main drive screw needs to be fairly solid or it will become too brittle. I first printed it with a 3.5mm fill spacing and then promptly dropped it on the floor which caused it to break in two...
Update 120427: Added pcb_vise_v2-drive_screw_2parts_left and right which is simply the drivescrew split into two parts to help vertically challenged printers :)
Update 120428: Added pcb_vise_v2-Bracket_2parts_bracket_left and -right (sorry about the long names, they help me keep track of all the parts). There weren't a hole lot of room to add in any alignment helpers here but I hope you can manage without them.

comments.text:
I just wanted to take some time to say thanks for the much anticipated vise. You ought to get more than just a small honorarium for your work here. I am still experiencing several issues with the PLA cracking on the swivel without tightening much, and as for the bracket; some warping of the back plane (in contact with the heater bed); sagging of the 12mm holes for the stopper/knob. Wish I had the answer, I am experimenting but still not happy with my progress, soon will be packaging my mistakes for family Xmas gift vices.
There are going to be limits I know considering the cost of this Anet A8, it is after all built to a price. But I can still try to make, as they say, a silk purse from a sow's ear.
I consider myself still in your debt :-)
comments.author: CanterburyFlyer

comments.text: Thanks! It works perfectly
comments.author: TheRapidPro

comments.text:
Great work. I'm tired of chasing my PCB using helping hands. I never seem to get the wing nuts tight enough on the HH. I've been wanting one of these for awhile but the cost was always too high IMHO. Thank you sir.
Print Notes: The jaws printed much better after rotating on X axis 90 degrees, added support material and 80% infill

title: Scalar - BLTouch Holder for E3DV6 / Lite Hotend

description.text:
Description

This thing is a HotEnd Holder compatible with Scalar 3D printers from 3D Modular Systems and E3DLite6 hotend.
This holder is compatible with BLTouch leveling sensor.

This thing is a remix from "s3rkan" who remiexed the original hotend holder to fit the BLTouch sensor. Thanks again to him

Updates

  • 2017.03.03 - Updated the BLtouch holder to make it adjustable in height

Compatibility

Compatible with:

  • E3DLite6 hotend
  • E3DV6 hotend
  • BLTouch or compatible sensors

Documentation

Upgrade documentation for Scalar 3D printers is available here:
http://doc.3dmodularsystems.com/upgrade-bltouch-for-scalar-3d-printers/

Nuts an bolts

You will need mainly thermoplastic screws

  • 4 x M3x8 for BLTouch holder
  • 4 x M3x20 for hotend holder
  • 1 x M3x8 for Hotend Holder

Adjustements

You may have to adjust ZOffset once after you have mounted this system based on how the hotend is assembled.

Compatible Firmware

BLTouch is compatible with RC8 and later version of Marlin firmware.
You need to activate the BLTouch functionality inside the firmware.
We provided a sample firmware to show how the BLTouch was configured (check configuration.h).

Wiring and documentation

The 3 pins connector of the BLTouch is to be connected to the SERVO_0 pins.
1 jumper is to be added to provide the +5V to the servo power line.
The 2 pins connector is to be connected to the ZMin inputs of the ramps.

for more information please check BLTouch Official Webpage and documentation:
https://www.indiegogo.com/projects/bltouch-auto-bed-leveling-sensor-for-3d-printers#/

Enjoy 3D Printing

3D Modular Systems
Evolutive 3D Printers

You enjoy it and want to help us with a donation: https://www.paypal.me/3DMS

http://www.3dmodularsystems.com
Twitter: https://twitter.com/3dmodularsystem
Youtube: http://www.youtube.com/c/3DModularSystems3DPrinters

title: Anet A8 3DTouch/BLTouch Auto Leveling Sensor Bracket

description.text:
Update 30-APR-2017: I added the config file that I’ve been giving to people who ask for my config file. The configuration enclosed is the original 5 button configuration file of SkynetV2.3.1 modified to support 3DTouch/BLTouch. Note that this is for SkynetV2.3.1.
--- End of update ---

The 3DTouch/BLTouch sensor is a servo based sensor. Its main advantage is that it allows you to easily move between printing on glass or directly on the bed, without having to adjust auto leveling parameters. This sensor requires an additional pin that isn’t easily available on the Anet V1/Sanguinololu control board. To use this sensor on an Anet A8, you either have to move to a different board, modify the LCD cabling (see http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2091529), or free up a pin on the Anet board by converting the display to I2C. See my design for freeing up a pin: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2098646 .

There are several 3DTouch brackets available on Thingiverse. Most won’t fit the Anet A8. The one that I found that would probably fit (http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2084025 ) moves the sensor so that it’s almost in line with the fan, and it’s right next to the extruder cooling fins. This limits the bed area available to the probe in the Y direction. My design limits the X direction, but less than the limitation of the design that limits the Y direction.

My design will only work on Anet A8s that have the same hole pattern on the extruder carriage as mine. This is a very tight fit. It should not touch anything and is greater than the manufacturer's minimum suggested distance of 15mm from the hot end/nozzle.

Prints: SensorBracket.stl, AlignmentSpacer.stl
I printed both at 100% fill, 0.1mm, support “Touching Bed". I’m not a print settings expert, but I figured the bracket needs to be as rigid as possible. The alignment spacer is the distance from the base of the sensor to the bed when the nozzle is a paper thickness above the bed. The spacer is only as precise as your printer. Mine was dead on (today). It should measure 8.3mm on a good day.

Mount the sensor on the bracket before attaching the bracket to the extruder carriage.

Use Repetier-Host, Cura, etc., to place the nozzle the thickness of a sheet of paper off the bed. Use the alignment widget to set the height of the sensor above the bed.

Some of the Marlin/SkynetV2.3.1 Configuration.h settings: (the others you can get from the manufacturer’s documentation)
I determined these two offsets using the grid file "Coords mm.pdf"
define X_PROBE_OFFSET_FROM_EXTRUDER 59 // X offset: -left +right [of the nozzle]
define Y_PROBE_OFFSET_FROM_EXTRUDER 14 // Y offset: -front +behind [the nozzle]
The Z_PROBE_OFFSET_FROM_EXTRUDER setting should be set based on your actual results you measure during setup.

define LEFT_PROBE_BED_POSITION 15
define RIGHT_PROBE_BED_POSITION 195
define BACK_PROBE_BED_POSITION 205
define FRONT_PROBE_BED_POSITION 25

If you use a non-standard servo pin you’ll need to define SERVO0_PIN. In my case it’s 27.
define SERVO0_PIN 27

DO NOT attempt to do an Auto Home after your very first upload. Send one of the test gcodes to make sure you're connected.
M280 P0 S10 ; pushes the pin down
M280 P0 S90 ; pulls the pin up
M280 P0 S120 ; Self test – keeps going until you do pin up/down or release alarm
M280 P0 S160 ; Release alarm

Hardware: (2) M3 x 8, (2) M3 x 12, (4) M3 nuts

author: frederickrelyea

description.text: My version of 6 nuts fidget spinner. It's my favourite version of it so far :)

Taking off bolts multiple times out of an aluminum heat sink could damage the thread. This casing I designed gives a protection from hot metal as well as provide mounting for possible deigned brackets.

You can design your own mount based on the available holes. The hole is M3 diameter.
The distance of the holes are match the 40mm fan and the 30 mm fan holes. They are about 32mm and 24 mm respectively.

Also, it gives a neat look and better cable management.

Printer:

TEVO Tarantula Prusa i3 - ReEngineered

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.15mm (best to handle hole)

Infill:

Any (1.3 mm thickness wall)

Notes:

I'm using ABS to handle the heat temperature on the heat sink.
I found the slower speed the better to print the curve overlaps.
I used 20mm/s for minimum speed.
Good retraction setting is needed.
The other side has holes for brackets, as well as the back. So you can attach fan shroud on the side or from the back. Dual radial fan brackets - Perfect for PLA printing

I am using Autodesk Fusion 360 to design this housing.
The gantry bracket that I used currently is the Fankhauser's modular aluminum carriage, which I put it up side down.

The design is still in progress.
I am upgrading the height.

Feature Added:

  • Dual radial fans bracket (remixed from: Supasorn's design - http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1850163) - in this remixed, i adjusted the width and the trunks thickness (easier to print without support)

license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
A stackable sorting or prep tray for 25mm figures (or thereabouts) that I cobbled together on the request of a friend. Includes a few extra 1" - 25mm hex bases as fillers with a minimum 0.5" safety margin around edge of the frame. Use final box with or without inserts, permanently glued or not.

Formatted for cutting on 3mm MDF cut from 24" x 18" (Arch C sheet size) - one sheet fits across the bed of an Epilog Helix. I have provided the PDF and a SVG file that I converted online at https://cloudconvert.com/vsd-to-svg. Shared as is.

If you are inclined to be more than a taker and a consumer, pay forward by contributing to this site, as so many others have before you, or perform a random act of kindness, or donate to a good cause when the opportunity next arises.
